tourName: Central India holiday, journey through Chhattisgarh
placesVisited: Discover three of Chhattisgarh’s wildlife sanctuaries, home to: leopards, Indian giant squirrels, wild dogs, hill mynahs and Malabar trogons, Explore the ancient city of Sirpur and the holy site of Amarkantak, the source of the Narmada River, Experience a colourful haat (weekly market) of the Baiga, Maria, Muria and Gond tribal communities, Visit bell metal, terracotta, wrought iron and weaving workshops, Enjoy the services of a naturalist guide as well as a specialist tour leader
generalInfo:
This fascinating two week tour of Chhattisgarh in Central India takes you well off the tourist trail in the company of English-speaking local experts. Experience ancient cities, wildlife sanctuaries, holy shrines, and authentic tribal markets as you embark on a journey that invites you into the unknown, and beyond.

From the protected surrounds of Achanakmar Tiger Reserve and Barnawapara Wildlife Sanctuary, you’ll be promised every opportunity to observe Indian animals in their natural habitat. Your first glimpse of a big cat or a giant squirrel in the wild is not something that you’re going to forget in a hurry.

Additional visits to tribal villages provide enlightenment of a cultural kind whilst overnight accommodation in comfy rural home stays, guesthouses and palatial properties provide further insight, as well as good night’s rest.

Your specialist tour leader will allow you every chance to tailor the tour your way however, you will be in thoroughly safe and experienced hands.

Sometimes it’s best to do as the Narmada River, and just go with the flow.

dayInfo.description: Raipur – Achanakmar Tiger Reserve: Upon arrival in Raipur you will be met by our team and transferred to your comfortable lodge at Keonchi village. The drive of 4 hours (200km) will take you north-east from Raipur into the lush forests of the Maikal hills of which Achanakmar Tiger Reserve and Amarkantak are both a part. In the evening you will be taken on a nature walk in the Sal forest. Later you will have a chance to see local culture in the form of a Gond tribal dance.

Achanakmar Tiger Reserve: Amarkantak is situated in the Maikal hills which is the source of the holy Narmada. The mountains of the Maikal hills of the Satpura range are home to many medicinal plants and an abundansce of wildlife. An area of 550 sq km is declared as Achanakmar Wildlife Sanctuary and Tiger Reserve. In these forests many ethnic tribal communities also live still following their age old traditions. There are plenty of things to do at Achanakmar. Your day begins with a game safari in Achanakmar Tiger Reserve where you have the chance to see cheetal (spotted deer), wild boar, gaur (Indian bison), sambhar deer, leopard, langur, giant squirrel and array of beautiful birds. If you are really lucky you might also see a tiger. You can also visit Bhanwartank lake, an ideal spot for birdwatching and angling. You can have a picnic breakfast here while watching birds. In the evenings you can drive to Mandwa Rani, the confluence of the rivers Narmada and Son, or you can visit local tribal villages and see something of village life rural India. At Keonchi you can also visit the Herbal Medicine Centre run by the Forest Department. In the evening you can also visit a colourful tribal haat (weekly market). A visit to the holy site of Amarkantak, source of the holy river Narmada and its temples is also a rewarding experience. Amarkantak is located at a distance of 22 kms from your resort and a half day tour can be organised.

Achanakmar – Barnawapara Wildlife Sanctuary: After breakfast start for Barnawapara Wildlife Sanctuary. The drive will take approximately 5 hours (250 km) to reach Muba resort in time for lunch. Rooms of the Muba resort are built in machaan style above the ground and provide lovely views of the forest below.

Barnawapara Wildlife Sanctuary: The major wildlife of Barnawapara Sanctuary includes leopard, wild dog, sloth bear, jungle cat, small Indian civet, gaur, sambhar, chital, nilgai, wild boar, jackal, hyena and barking deer. Due to the absence of tigers other species have flourished, with leopard and gaur having benefited the most. Tourism here is still in its nascent stages. You can go on an evening and morning safari in the sanctuary in search of wildlife. There is also the opportunity for forest treks, a rare thing in Indian wildlife sanctuaries and, we feel, the very best way fully to experience the sights and sounds of the jungle.

Barnawapara-Sirpur-Kanker: After breakfast at Barnawapara a short, one hour, drive takes you to the ancient city of Sirpur. Sirpur or Sripura as it was known in historic times had a splendid intermix of cultures dating from the 5th to the 10th century AD relating to Buddhist, Shaiva, Vaishnava and Jain culture. This can be seen in many of the sites, for example the Laxman temple (dedicated to lord Vishnu). The temple is considered as one of the finest brick temples of India with a stone doorframe. ancient Buddhist Sangharama or monastery, said to be bigger than the great Nalanda university itself. The Buddhist Vihar, found during excavations, is magnificent and it's the biggest temple complex of 6th and 7th centuries to be covered so far. Other sites include Surang Tilla, Tivaradeva Mahavihar, Anandprabha Kutir Vihar and various temple complexes. After visiting Sirpur continue to Kanker (200 kms/4hours). You will be a carrying picnic lunch for the journey which will be taken, en route, in the forest. You will be received with a traditional welcome at Kanker Palace by your royal hosts. After settling into your large palace rooms, you will be entertained by Chhattisgarhi folk musicians over drinks and pre-dinner snacks. Members of the family will join you to share their experiences of living in the region.

Kanker: Explore the beautiful surroundings of the palace and the small town of Kanker. Visit a Deer-horn Muria village and get a glimpse of their unique dormitory system, the gotul. Here you can enjoy wonderful village food in the company of locals, along with some locally brewed toddy. Later in the evening you can observe and enjoy tribal life up close while visiting a tribal haat. Note: Haats are weekly markets, you will need to check with us in advance for the market days.

Kanker-Jagdalpur: After breakfast climb the winding ghats of Keshkal valley to reach Jagdalpur. It is the largest town in the region and the headquarters of the Bastar district. You will be carrying a packed lunch from the palace which will be taken in the forest. You will make a short de-tour midway to visit tribal craft communities of Kondagaon. You can see the artesian working on bell metal, wrought iron, terracotta and wood. Reach Jagdalpur in time for evening snacks and drinks at a jungle resort set amidst nature away from the crowded city of Jagdalpur.

Jagdalpur and environs: A few days in the capable hands of our local guide will give you a chance to tap the tribal and natural delights of this area. You will travel with him out of Jagdalpur into the country of the Bison Horn Maria and Dhurwa tribes. You will see a performance of their spectacular local dance and get a good look at village life, costumes, ornaments and customs. You will visit villages and tribal markets and see the Chitrakote Waterfalls on the Indravati River. In the evenings there will be further opportunities to explore Jagdalpur's absorbing city markets. You will also have time to visit Kanger Valley National Park an hour or so south of Jagdalpur where there are also famous stalactite and stalagmite formations in the Kutumsar and Kailash Caves. However the real glory of Kanger is that it retains something of the intensity of the forests that once covered this entire region - the natural habitat of leopard, tiger, sambhar, bison and the musical hill myna, Bastar's most famous bird and the state bird of Chhattisgarh.

Jagdalpur-Kanker: Return to Kanker for a final night at the palace. You may choose to relax and ask for a rejuvenating massage or take up a cooking lesson from Jolly who is an expert cook. If time permits, you may also visit the back waters of Mahanadi river in evening for bird watching.

Kanker-Raipur: Drive back to Raipur to catch flight/train for your onward journey. Note: You have an option of extending this tour to Bhoramdeo to see more of rural India and to meet Baiga people, and further still to Kanha National Park.
